s.text: performed all of the studies described and wrote the draft of the manuscript.

Additionally, the mutant confirms previous work that the two known LcrG functions (secretion blocking and LcrV interaction) are genetically separable [ 5 ] . Further experiments will more precisely delineate the region of LcrG required to block the type III secretion apparatus.

LcrG and LcrV physically interact in Y. pestis [ 4 ] , and that interaction plays a significant role in the regulation of Yops secretion [ 20 ] . LcrG and LcrV interact in a yeast two-hybrid assay [ 20 ] , therefore this technique was used to further investigate the region of LcrG required for its interaction with LcrV.
Cloning methods were essentially as described previously [ 31 ] . PCR fragments were purified using the QiaQuick PCR purification kit (Qiagen).

Secreted proteins were recovered from the bacterial growth medium by centrifuging the spent medium a second time, transferring the supernatant to a clean tube, and precipitating with 10% (vol/vol) TCA on ice overnight.

Proteins resolved by SDS-PAGE were transferred to Immobilon-P membranes (Millipore Corp., Bedford, MA) using carbonate transfer buffer (pH 9.9) [ 5 ] . Specific proteins were visualized using rabbit polyclonal antibodies specific for glutathione S-transferase (GST)-tagged LcrG (?-LcrG) [ 4 ] , His-tagged LcrV (?-LcrV) [ 4 ] , YopM (?-YopM) [ 36 ] , GST-tagged LcrQ (?-LcrQ) [ 16 ] , YopN (aka LcrE) (?-LcrE [ 4 ] ), His-tagged YopD (?-YopD) [ 16 ] , and YopE (?-YopE; gift from S. C. Straley, University of Kentucky, Lexington, KY.

Secreted proteins were recovered from the bacterial growth medium by centrifuging the spent medium a second time, transferring the supernatant to a clean tube, and precipitating with 10% (vol/vol) TCA on ice overnight.

Secreted proteins were recovered from the bacterial growth medium by centrifuging the spent medium a second time, transferring the supernatant to a clean tube, and precipitating with 10% (vol/vol) TCA on ice overnight.
Mutation of F48 to either alanine or leucine had no effect on the function of those LcrG variants, suggesting that the hydrophobic nature of F48 is important for LcrG function.
This information suggested that residue 39 of LcrG was an ideal candidate for site-directed mutagenesis to disrupt LcrG's secretion blocking activity.

This result suggests that a region of PcrG including amino acid 42 is capable of interaction with Y. pestis secretion components and suggests that the homologous LcrG region is likely to be involved in LcrG's secretion-blocking activity.
Mutation of F48 to either alanine or leucine had no effect on the function of those LcrG variants, suggesting that the hydrophobic nature of F48 is important for LcrG function.

As coiled-coil motifs show a characteristic seven amino acid repeat pattern, with each repeat representing two turns of the ?-helix, it is interesting that three positions identified as important to the LcrG-LcrV interaction (16, 23, and 30) are each separated by seven amino acids.

As coiled-coil motifs show a characteristic seven amino acid repeat pattern, with each repeat representing two turns of the ?-helix, it is interesting that three positions identified as important to the LcrG-LcrV interaction (16, 23, and 30) are each separated by seven amino acids.

Yeast two-hybrid assays were performed as recommended by the commercial supplier (Clontech, Palo Alto, CA).

Additionally, the mutant confirms previous work that the two known LcrG functions (secretion blocking and LcrV interaction) are genetically separable [ 5 ] . Further experiments will more precisely delineate the region of LcrG required to block the type III secretion apparatus.
Mutation of F48 to either alanine or leucine had no effect on the function of those LcrG variants, suggesting that the hydrophobic nature of F48 is important for LcrG function.

These residues are likely to reside on the same face of the protein if a coiled-coil structure is assumed.

The color change of the yeast colonies due to the hydrolysis of 5-bromo-4-chloro-3-indolyl-?-D-galactopyranoside (X-gal) by ?-galactosidase was significantly delayed and less intense than the reaction we observed for strongly interacting mutants.

The color change of the yeast colonies due to the hydrolysis of 5-bromo-4-chloro-3-indolyl-?-D-galactopyranoside (X-gal) by ?-galactosidase was significantly delayed and less intense than the reaction we observed for strongly interacting mutants.
